summary.abstract: This encyclopedia article surveys cartographic activities in Islamic societies from the early Islamic period through the twentieth century, tracing the influence of two formative encounters in Abbasid Baghdad: the translation of Ptolemy's Geography and the adaptation of possibly Sasanian regional maps. The article identifies four major mapmaking cultures in the Islamic world—the Ptolemaic tradition, the Balkhī school, Ottoman maritime cartography, and Ottoman court mapping—each characterized by distinctive methods, formats, and cultural purposes. Special attention is given to the qibla determination maps, climatic zone diagrams, and the fusion of multiple cartographic traditions in world maps. The article also follows modern cartography in Iran through the Qajar period and twentieth-century institutional development of cartographic organizations.

contents.heading: Cartography and Surveying in Iran in the Twentieth Century
